Package com.github.yellowstonegames.core

Class DescriptiveColorRgb

java.lang.Object
com.github.yellowstonegames.core.DescriptiveColorRgb
public final class DescriptiveColorRgb extends Object
A palette, the same as the one in DescriptiveColor, just using RGBA8888 ints instead of Oklab ints for each color entry. This provides the same ways of looking up colors, as well as most of the same ways to modify RGBA8888 int colors (or similar ways, at least).

    Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the ABGR7888 format libGDX uses.
    static int
    unevenMix(int... colors)
    Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color.
    static int
    unevenMix(int[] colors, int offset, int size)
    Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color.

    Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

    clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

  • Field Details

    • NAMED

      public static final com.github.tommyettinger.ds.ObjectIntOrderedMap<String> NAMED
      You can look up colors by name here; the names are lower-case, and the colors are packed ints in RGBA8888 format.

    • ALIASES

      public static final com.github.tommyettinger.ds.ObjectIntOrderedMap<String> ALIASES
      Stores alternative names for colors in NAMED, like "grey" as an alias for GRAY or "gold" as an alias for SAFFRON. Currently, the list of aliases is as follows:
      • "grey" maps to GRAY,
      • "gold" maps to SAFFRON,
      • "puce" maps to MAUVE,
      • "sand" maps to TAN,
      • "skin" maps to PEACH,
      • "coral" maps to SALMON,
      • "azure" maps to SKY, and
      • "ocean" maps to TEAL, and
      • "sapphire" maps to COBALT.
      Note that these aliases are not duplicated in NAMES, NAMES_BY_HUE, or NAMES_BY_LIGHTNESS; they are primarily there so blind attempts to name a color might still work.

    • LIST

      public static final com.github.tommyettinger.ds.IntList LIST

    • PLACEHOLDER

      public static final int PLACEHOLDER
      A fully-transparent color that is not exactly transparent black (rather, transparent very dark blue), to be used as a placeholder for colors that aren't valid in some way. This is not included in NAMED or LIST.

    • NAMES

      public static final com.github.tommyettinger.ds.ObjectList<String> NAMES
      All names for colors in this palette, in alphabetical order. You can fetch the corresponding packed int color by looking up a name in NAMED.

    • NAMES_BY_HUE

      public static final com.github.tommyettinger.ds.ObjectList<String> NAMES_BY_HUE
      All names for colors in this palette, with grayscale first, then sorted by hue from red to yellow to green to blue. You can fetch the corresponding packed int color by looking up a name in NAMED. This does not include aliases.

    • COLORS_BY_HUE

      public static final com.github.tommyettinger.ds.IntList COLORS_BY_HUE
      The packed RGBA8888 int colors that correspond to items in NAMES_BY_HUE, with the same order.

    • NAMES_BY_LIGHTNESS

      public static final com.github.tommyettinger.ds.ObjectList<String> NAMES_BY_LIGHTNESS
      All names for colors in this palette, sorted by lightness from black to white. You can fetch the corresponding packed int color by looking up a name in NAMED. This does not include aliases.

  • Method Details

    • rgba

      public static int rgba(float r, float g, float b, float a)
      Gets an RGBA int color given a float per channel. This method maps each channel from the 0 to 1 float range here, to the 0 to 255 int range in the result.
      Parameters:
      r - red channel; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
      g - green channel; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
      b - blue channel; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
      a - alpha channel; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
      Returns:
      the RGBA color matching the given channels, as an RGBA8888 int

    • fromFloat

      public static int fromFloat(float packed)
      Converts a packed float color in the format libGDX uses (ABGR7888) to an RGBA8888 int as this class uses.
      Parameters:
      packed - a packed float color in ABGR7888 format
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int color

    • toFloat

      public static float toFloat(int rgba)
      Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the ABGR7888 format libGDX uses.
      Parameters:
      rgba - an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
      Returns:
      a packed float color as ABGR7888

    • redInt

      public static int redInt(int rgba)

      public static float red(int rgba)

    • greenInt

      public static int greenInt(int rgba)

      public static float green(int rgba)

    • blueInt

      public static float blue(int rgba)

    • alphaInt

      public static int alphaInt(int rgba)

    • alpha

      public static float alpha(int rgba)

    • channel

      public static float channel(int color, int channel)
      Given a packed int color and a channel value from 0 to 3, gets the value of that channel as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f . Channel 0 refers to R in RGBA8888 and H in HSLA ints, channel 1 refers to G or S, 2 refers to B or L, and 3 always refers to A.
      Parameters:
      color - a packed int color in any 32-bit, 4-channel format
      channel - which channel to access, as an index from 0 to 3 inclusive
      Returns:
      the value of the requested channel, from 0.0f to 1.0f inclusive

    • channelInt

      public static int channelInt(int color, int channel)
      Given a packed int color and a channel value from 0 to 3, gets the value of that channel as an int from 0 to 255 . Channel 0 refers to R in RGBA8888 and H in HSLA ints, channel 1 refers to G or S, 2 refers to B or L, and 3 always refers to A.
      Parameters:
      color - a packed int color in any 32-bit, 4-channel format
      channel - which channel to access, as an index from 0 to 3 inclusive
      Returns:
      the int value of the requested channel, from 0 to 255 inclusive

    • editRgba

      public static int editRgba(int rgba, float addR, float addG, float addB, float addA)

    • editRgba

      public static int editRgba(int rgba, float addR, float addG, float addB, float addA, float mulR, float mulG, float mulB, float mulA)

    • hsl2rgb

      public static int hsl2rgb(float h, float s, float l, float a)
      Converts the four HSLA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to an int in RGBA8888 format. I brought this over from colorful-gdx's FloatColors class. I can't recall where I got the original HSL(A) code from, but there's a strong chance it was written by cypherdare/cyphercove for their color space comparison. The h parameter for hue can be lower than 0.0 or higher than 1.0 because the hue "wraps around;" only the fractional part of h is used. The other parameters must be between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive) to make sense.
      Parameters:
      h - hue, usually from 0.0 to 1.0, but only the fractional part is used
      s - saturation, from 0.0 to 1.0
      l - lightness, from 0.0 to 1.0
      a - alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888-format int

    • rgb2hsl

      public static int rgb2hsl(float r, float g, float b, float a)
      Converts the four RGBA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to an int in HSLA format (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha). This format is exactly like RGBA8888 but treats what would normally be red as hue, green as saturation, and blue as lightness; alpha is the same.
      Parameters:
      r - red, from 0.0 to 1.0
      g - green, from 0.0 to 1.0
      b - blue, from 0.0 to 1.0
      a - alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
      Returns:
      an "HSLA-format" int

    • hsl2rgb

      public static int hsl2rgb(int hsla)
      Converts the given "HSLA-format" int color to an int color in the RGBA8888 format. I brought this over from colorful-gdx's FloatColors class. I can't recall where I got the original HSL(A) code from, but there's a strong chance it was written by cypherdare/cyphercove for their color space comparison. The h parameter for hue can be lower than 0.0 or higher than 1.0 because the hue "wraps around;" only the fractional part of h is used. The other parameters must be between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive) to make sense.
      Parameters:
      hsla - an "HSLA-format" int, as produced by rgb2hsl(int)
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888-format int

    • rgb2hsl

      public static int rgb2hsl(int rgba)
      Converts the given RGBA8888 int color to an int in HSLA format (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha). This format is exactly like RGBA8888 but treats what would normally be red as hue, green as saturation, and blue as lightness; alpha is the same.
      Parameters:
      rgba - an RGBA8888 int color
      Returns:
      an "HSLA-format" int

    • hcl2rgb

      public static int hcl2rgb(float h, float c, float l, float a)
      Converts the four HCLA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to an int in RGBA8888 format. I brought this over from colorful-gdx's FloatColors class. I can't recall where I got the original HSL(A) code from, but there's a strong chance it was written by cypherdare/cyphercove for their color space comparison. The h parameter for hue can be lower than 0.0 or higher than 1.0 because the hue "wraps around;" only the fractional part of h is used. The other parameters must be between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive) to make sense.
      Parameters:
      h - hue, usually from 0.0 to 1.0, but only the fractional part is used
      c - chroma, from 0.0 to 1.0; higher chroma values may be out-of-gamut
      l - lightness, from 0.0 to 1.0
      a - alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888-format int

    • rgb2hcl

      public static int rgb2hcl(float r, float g, float b, float a)
      Converts the four RGBA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to an int in HCLA format (hue, chroma, lightness, alpha). This format is exactly like RGBA8888 but treats what would normally be red as hue, green as saturation, and blue as lightness; alpha is the same.
      Parameters:
      r - red, from 0.0 to 1.0
      g - green, from 0.0 to 1.0
      b - blue, from 0.0 to 1.0
      a - alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
      Returns:
      an "HCLA-format" int

    • hcl2rgb

      public static int hcl2rgb(int hcla)
      Converts the given "HCLA-format" int color to an int color in the RGBA8888 format. This format is mostly produced by rgb2hcl(int).
      I brought this over from colorful-gdx's FloatColors class. I can't recall where I got the original HSL(A) code from, but there's a strong chance it was written by cypherdare/cyphercove for their color space comparison. The h parameter for hue can be lower than 0.0 or higher than 1.0 because the hue "wraps around;" only the fractional part of h is used. The other parameters must be between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive) to make sense.
      Parameters:
      hcla - an "HCLA-format" int, as produced by rgb2hcl(int)
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888-format int

    • rgb2hcl

      public static int rgb2hcl(int rgba)
      Converts the given RGBA8888 int color to an int in HCLA format (hue, chroma, lightness, alpha). This format is exactly like RGBA8888 but treats what would normally be red as hue, green as saturation, and blue as lightness; alpha is the same.
      Parameters:
      rgba - an RGBA8888 int color
      Returns:
      an "HCLA-format" int

    • hsb2rgb

      public static int hsb2rgb(float h, float s, float b, float a)
      Converts the four HSBA/HSVA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to an int in RGBA8888 format. I brought this over from colorful-gdx's FloatColors class. I can't recall where I got the original HSL(A) code from, but there's a strong chance it was written by cypherdare/cyphercove for their color space comparison. HSV and HSB are synonyms; it makes a little more sense to call the third channel brightness. The h parameter for hue can be lower than 0.0 or higher than 1.0 because the hue "wraps around;" only the fractional part of h is used. The other parameters must be between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive) to make sense.
      Parameters:
      h - hue, from 0.0 to 1.0
      s - saturation, from 0.0 to 1.0
      b - brightness, from 0.0 to 1.0
      a - alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888-format int

    • rgb2hsb

      public static int rgb2hsb(float r, float g, float b, float a)
      Converts the four RGBA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to an int in HSBA/HSVA format (hue, saturation, brightness/value, alpha). This format is exactly like RGBA8888 but treats what would normally be red as hue, green as saturation, and blue as brightness/value; alpha is the same. HSV and HSB are synonyms; it makes a little more sense to call the third channel brightness.
      Parameters:
      r - red, from 0.0 to 1.0
      g - green, from 0.0 to 1.0
      b - blue, from 0.0 to 1.0
      a - alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
      Returns:
      an "HSBA/HSVA-format" int

    • hsb2rgb

      public static int hsb2rgb(int hsba)
      Converts the given "HSBA-format" int color to an int color in the RGBA8888 format. This format is mostly produced by rgb2hsb(int).
      I brought this over from colorful-gdx's FloatColors class. I can't recall where I got the original HSL(A) code from, but there's a strong chance it was written by cypherdare/cyphercove for their color space comparison. HSV and HSB are synonyms; it makes a little more sense to call the third channel brightness. The h parameter for hue can be lower than 0.0 or higher than 1.0 because the hue "wraps around;" only the fractional part of h is used. The other parameters must be between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive) to make sense.
      Parameters:
      hsba - an "HSBA-format" int, as produced by rgb2hsb(int)
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888-format int

    • rgb2hsb

      public static int rgb2hsb(int rgba)
      Converts the given RGBA8888 int color to an int in HSBA/HSVA format (hue, brightness, lightness, alpha). This format is exactly like RGBA8888 but treats what would normally be red as hue, green as saturation, and blue as brightness (also called value); alpha is the same. HSV and HSB are synonyms; it makes a little more sense to call the third channel brightness.
      Parameters:
      rgba - an RGBA8888 int color
      Returns:
      an "HSBA/HSVA-format" int

    • hue

      public static float hue(int rgba)
      Gets the hue of the given RGBA8888 color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased) to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
      Parameters:
      rgba - a color as an RGBA8888 int
      Returns:
      The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)

    • saturation

      public static float saturation(int rgba)
      Gets the saturation of the given RGBA8888 color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive. Saturation is a related concept to chroma(int); saturation is simply chroma mapped to a range where 0.0 chroma is 0.0 saturation, and the highest possible chroma (which is almost always less than 1) is 1.0 saturation.
      Parameters:
      rgba - a color as an RGBA8888 int
      Returns:
      the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)

    • chroma

      public static float chroma(int rgba)
      Gets the chroma of the given RGBA8888 color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive. Chroma is a related concept to saturation(int); saturation is simply chroma mapped to a range where 0.0 chroma is 0.0 saturation, and the highest possible chroma (which is almost always less than 1) is 1.0 saturation.
      Parameters:
      rgba - a color as an RGBA8888 int
      Returns:
      the chroma of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (the most colorful a color can be, inclusive)

    • lightness

      public static float lightness(int rgba)
      Gets the lightness of the given RGBA8888 color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive. This uses the same measurement as rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float).
      Parameters:
      rgba - a color as an RGBA8888 int
      Returns:
      the lightness of the color from 0.0 (black; inclusive) to 1.0 (white; inclusive)

    • brightness

      public static float brightness(int rgba)
      Gets the brightness of the given RGBA8888 color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive. This uses the same measurement as rgb2hsb(float, float, float, float). Note that while lightness(int) returns 1.0 only if given white as its input, this returns 1.0 for white, all colors that are as colorful as possible (the ones with the highest chroma), and all colors in between white and one of those high-chroma colors. Most usage that compares colors for perceptual lightness will want lightness(int), not this method.
      Parameters:
      rgba - a color as an RGBA8888 int
      Returns:
      the brightness of the color from 0.0 (black; inclusive) to 1.0 (any bright color and/or white; inclusive)

    • raiseRed

      public static int raiseRed(int start, float change)
      Brings the red channel closer to its maximum, by change. The change should be between 0f (no change) and 1f (increase red to 1.0, or 255 as an int).
      Parameters:
      start - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int
      change - how much to go from start toward max red, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means more red
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color based on start
      See Also:
      • the counterpart method that lowers the red channel

    • lowerRed

      public static int lowerRed(int start, float change)
      Brings the red channel closer to its minimum, by change. The change should be between 0f (no change) and 1f (reduce red to 0).
      Parameters:
      start - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int
      change - how much to go from start toward max red, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means more red
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color based on start
      See Also:
      • the counterpart method that raises the red channel

    • blot

      public static int blot(int start, float change)
      Interpolates from the RGBA8888 int color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be an RGBA8888 int, as from rgba(float, float, float, float). This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors. This won't change the R, G, or B of the color.
      Parameters:
      start - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int
      change - how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color between start and its opaque version
      See Also:
      • the counterpart method that makes an RGBA color more translucent

    • fade

      public static int fade(int start, float change)
      Interpolates from the RGBA8888 int color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with 0 alpha), start should be an RGBA8888 int, as from rgba(float, float, float, float). This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors. This won't change the R, G, or B of the color.
      Parameters:
      start - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int
      change - how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color between start and transparent
      See Also:
      • the counterpart method that makes an RGBA color more opaque

    • multiplyAlpha

      public static int multiplyAlpha(int start, float multiplier)
      Multiplies the alpha of the RGBA int color start by multiplier. The start should be a packed color, as from rgba(float, float, float, float). The resulting alpha will be clamped between 0.0 and 1.0. This won't change the R, G, or B of the color.
      Parameters:
      start - the starting color as a packed RGBA8888 int
      multiplier - will be multiplied with the alpha of start
      Returns:
      a packed RGBA8888 int that represents a color like start, but with potentially a different alpha

    • setAlpha

      public static int setAlpha(int start, float newAlpha)
      Changes the alpha of the RGBA int color start to match newAlpha. The start should be a packed color, as from rgba(float, float, float, float). This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors. This won't change the R, G, or B of the color.
      Parameters:
      start - the starting color as a packed RGBA8888 int
      newAlpha - the alpha value to use, from 0.0f to 1.0f as a float
      Returns:
      a packed RGBA8888 int that represents a color like start, but with potentially a different alpha

    • lighten

      public static int lighten(int start, float change)
      Interpolates from the RGBA8888 color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be an RGBA8888 int color, as from rgba(float, float, float, float). This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using lerpColors(int, int, float) to lerp towards white. Unlike lerpColors(int, int, float), this keeps the alpha of start as-is.
      Parameters:
      start - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int
      change - how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color between start and white
      See Also:
      • the counterpart method that darkens a color

    • darken

      public static int darken(int start, float change)
      Interpolates from the RGBA8888 color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be an RGBA8888 int color, as from rgba(float, float, float, float). This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using lerpColors(int, int, float) to lerp towards black. Unlike lerpColors(int, int, float), this keeps the alpha of start as-is.
      Parameters:
      start - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int
      change - how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color between start and black
      See Also:
      • the counterpart method that lightens a color

    • adjustLightness

      public static int adjustLightness(int rgba, float change)
      Interpolates from the RGBA8888 int color rgba towards either white or black, depending on change. The value for change should be between -1f and 1f; negative values interpolate toward black, while positive ones interpolate toward white. The value for rgba should be an RGBA8888 int, as from a constant here.
      Parameters:
      rgba - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int
      change - how much to go away from rgba, as a float between -1 and 1; negative to black, positive to white
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color between start and black or white
      See Also:
      • the counterpart method that darkens a color
      • the counterpart method that lightens a color
      • a method that adjusts both chroma and lightness

    • dullen

      public static int dullen(int start, float change)
      Brings the chromatic components of start closer to grayscale by change (desaturating them). While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be an RGBA8888 int color, as from rgba(float, float, float, float). This leaves alpha alone.
      The algorithm used is from here.
      Parameters:
      start - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int
      change - how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
      See Also:
      • the counterpart method that makes a color more saturated

    • enrich

      public static int enrich(int start, float change)
      Pushes the chromatic components of start away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be an RGBA8888 int color, as from rgba(float, float, float, float).
      The algorithm used is from here.
      Parameters:
      start - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int
      change - how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color between start and a saturated color
      See Also:
      • the counterpart method that makes a color less saturated

    • adjustChroma

      public static int adjustChroma(int rgba, float change)
      Brings the chromatic components of the RGBA8888 int color rgba either towards or away from grayscale, depending on change. The value for change should be between -1f and 1f; negative values interpolate toward grayscale, while positive ones interpolate away from grayscale. The value for rgba should be an RGBA8888 int, as from a constant here or rgba(float, float, float, float).
      Parameters:
      rgba - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int
      change - how much to go away from grayscale, as a float between -1 and 1; negative to gray, positive away
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color between start but moved towards or away from grayscale
      See Also:
      • the counterpart method that makes a color closer to gray
      • the counterpart method that makes a color further from gray
      • a method that adjusts both chroma and lightness

    • adjustAll

      public static int adjustAll(int rgba, float lightness, float chroma)
      Effectively the same as calling adjustLightness(int, float) and then adjustChroma(int, float) on rgba and returning the result.
      Parameters:
      rgba - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int
      lightness - how much to go away from rgba, as a float between -1 and 1; negative to black, positive to white
      Returns:
      an int that represents an RGBA8888 color between rgba and black or white
      See Also:
      • the first step this performs
      • the second step this performs

    • lerpColors

      public static int lerpColors(int s, int e, float change)
      Interpolates from the RGBA8888 int color start towards end by change. Both start and end should be RGBA8888 ints, and change can be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use end). This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
      Parameters:
      s - the starting color as a packed int
      e - the end/target color as a packed int
      change - how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color between start and end

    • lerpColorsBlended

      public static int lerpColorsBlended(int s, int e, float change)
      Interpolates from the RGBA8888 int color start towards the RGBA8888 int color end by change, but keeps the alpha of start and uses the alpha of end as an extra factor that can affect how much to change. The colors (start and end) must be RGBA8888 ints, and change can be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use end). This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
      Parameters:
      s - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int; alpha will be preserved
      e - the target color as an RGBA8888 int; alpha will not be used directly, and will instead be multiplied with change
      change - how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color between start and end
      See Also:
      • mix(int[], int, int)

    • addColors

      public static int addColors(int s, int e)
      Mixes the int color start and the in color end additively. The colors (start and end) should be packed RGBA8888 ints. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors. This clamps each component to the valid range for an RGBA8888 int.
      The additive mixing this does will amplify any difference from GRAY, which is the neutral color here. If you mix several int colors that are each, approximately, grayish-green, then with enough colors the result will be a vivid, saturated green.
      This is probably faster than lerpColors(int, int, float) because it uses entirely int math, though the clamping it does might not help speed.
      Parameters:
      s - the starting color as an RGBA8888 int
      e - the end/target color as an RGBA8888 int
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int that represents a color between start and end
      See Also:
      • additiveMix(int[], int, int)

    • mix

      public static int mix(int[] colors, int offset, int size)
      Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure. If colors is null or has no items, this returns PLACEHOLDER. This is mostly useful in conjunction with IntList, using its items for colors, typically 0 for offset, and its size for size.
      Parameters:
      colors - an array of RGBA8888 int colors; all should use the same color space
      offset - the index of the first item in colors to use
      size - how many items from colors to use
      Returns:
      an even mix of all colors given, as an RGBA8888 int color

    • unevenMix

      public static int unevenMix(int... colors)
      Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color. Takes an array of varargs of alternating ints representing colors and weights, as with color, weight, color, weight.... If colors is null or has no items, this returns PLACEHOLDER. Each color should be an RGBA8888 int, and each weight should be greater than 0.
      Parameters:
      colors - an array or varargs that should contain alternating color, weight, color, weight... ints
      Returns:
      the mixed color, as an RGBA8888 int

    • unevenMix

      public static int unevenMix(int[] colors, int offset, int size)
      Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color. Takes an array of alternating ints representing colors and weights, as with color, weight, color, weight..., starting at offset in the array and continuing for size indices in the array. The size should be an even number 2 or greater, otherwise it will be reduced by 1. The weights can be any non-negative int values; this method handles normalizing them internally. Each color should an RGBA8888 int, and each weight should be greater than 0. If colors is null or has no items, or if size <= 0, this returns PLACEHOLDER.
      Parameters:
      colors - starting at offset, this should contain alternating color, weight, color, weight... ints
      offset - where to start reading from in colors
      size - how many indices to read from colors; must be an even number
      Returns:
      the mixed color, as an RGBA8888 int

    • additiveMix

      public static int additiveMix(int[] colors, int offset, int size)
      Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure, mixing them additively and clamping. If colors is null or has no items, this returns PLACEHOLDER (a transparent placeholder used to mean "no color found"). This is mostly useful in conjunction with IntList, using its items for colors, typically 0 for offset, and its size for size. The additive mixing this does will amplify any difference from GRAY, which is the neutral color here. If you mix several int colors that are each, approximately, grayish-green, then with enough colors the result will be a vivid, saturated green.
      This is probably faster than mix(int[], int, int) because this uses only int math, and should also be faster than individually mixing colors with addColors(int, int) because it only clamps once. This does produce different results than either of those.
      Parameters:
      colors - an array of RGBA8888 int colors
      offset - the index of the first item in colors to use
      size - how many items from colors to use
      Returns:
      an even mix of all colors given, as an RGBA8888 int color
      See Also:
      • addColors(int, int)

    • describe

      public static int describe(String description)
      Parses a color description and returns the approximate color it describes, as a packed RGBA8888 int color. Color descriptions consist of one or more alphabetical words, separated by non-alphanumeric characters (typically spaces and/or hyphens, though the underscore is treated as a letter). Any word that is the name of a color in this palette will be looked up in NAMED and tracked; if there is more than one of these color name words, the colors will be mixed using unevenMix(int[], int, int), or if there is just one color name word, then the corresponding color will be used. A number can be present after a color name (separated by any non-alphanumeric character(s) other than the underscore); if so, it acts as a positive weight for that color when mixed with other named colors. The recommended separator between a color name and its weight is the space ' ', but other punctuation like ':', or whitespace, is usually valid. Note that in some contexts, color descriptions shouldn't contain square brackets, curly braces, or the chars @%?^=. , because they can have unintended effects on the behavior of markup. You can also repeat a color name to increase its weight, as in "red red blue".
      The special adjectives "light" and "dark" change the lightness of the described color; likewise, "rich" and "dull" change the saturation (how different the color is from grayscale). All of these adjectives can have "-er" or "-est" appended to make their effect twice or three times as strong. Technically, the chars appended to an adjective don't matter, only their count, so "lightaa" is the same as "lighter" and "richcat" is the same as "richest". There's an unofficial fourth level as well, used when any 4 characters are appended to an adjective (as in "darkmost"); it has four times the effect of the original adjective. There are also the adjectives "bright" (equivalent to "light rich"), "pale" ("light dull"), "deep" ("dark rich"), and "weak" ("dark dull"). These can be amplified like the other four, except that "pale" goes to "paler", "palest", and then to "palemax" or (its equivalent) "palemost", where only the word length is checked. The case of adjectives doesn't matter here; they can be all-caps, all lower-case, or mixed-case without issues. The names of colors, however, are case-sensitive, because you can combine other named color palettes with the one here, and at least in one common situation (merging libGDX Colors with the palette here), the other palette uses all-caps names only.
      If part of a color name or adjective is invalid, it is not considered; if the description is empty or fully invalid, this returns the invalid "color" PLACEHOLDER (also used by TextraTypist, and suggested as a placeholder for other code).
      Examples of valid descriptions include "blue", "dark green", "duller red", "peach pink", "indigo purple mauve", "lightest richer apricot-olive", "bright magenta", "palest cyan blue", "deep fern black", "weakmost celery", "red:3 orange", and "dark deep (blue 7) (cyan 3)".
      This method will check the first character of description and may change how it parses depending on that char. If the first char is #, and there are 6 characters remaining, this parses those 6 characters as a hex color in RGB888 format (treating it as opaque). If the first char is # and there are 8 or more characters remaining, it parses 8 of those characters as an RGBA8888 hex color. If the first char is |, that char is ignored and the rest of the CharSequence is treated as a color description (this is to ease parsing markup for DescriptiveColor.processColorMarkup(CharSequence)). Otherwise, the whole CharSequence is parsed as a color description, and the result is converted to an RGBA int.
      Parameters:
      description - a color description, as a String matching the above format, or a #-prefixed hex color
      Returns:
      a packed RGBA int color as described

    • describeRgb

      public static int describeRgb(String description)
      Parses a color description and returns the approximate color it describes, as a packed RGBA8888 int color. Color descriptions consist of one or more alphabetical words, separated by non-alphanumeric characters (typically spaces and/or hyphens, though the underscore is treated as a letter). Any word that is the name of a color in this palette will be looked up in NAMED and tracked; if there is more than one of these color name words, the colors will be mixed using unevenMix(int[], int, int), or if there is just one color name word, then the corresponding color will be used. A number can be present after a color name (separated by any non-alphanumeric character(s) other than the underscore); if so, it acts as a positive weight for that color when mixed with other named colors. The recommended separator between a color name and its weight is the space ' ', but other punctuation like ':', or whitespace, is usually valid. Note that in some contexts, color descriptions shouldn't contain square brackets, curly braces, or the chars @%?^=. , because they can have unintended effects on the behavior of markup. You can also repeat a color name to increase its weight, as in "red red blue".
      The special adjectives "light" and "dark" change the lightness of the described color; likewise, "rich" and "dull" change the saturation (how different the color is from grayscale). All of these adjectives can have "-er" or "-est" appended to make their effect twice or three times as strong. Technically, the chars appended to an adjective don't matter, only their count, so "lightaa" is the same as "lighter" and "richcat" is the same as "richest". There's an unofficial fourth level as well, used when any 4 characters are appended to an adjective (as in "darkmost"); it has four times the effect of the original adjective. There are also the adjectives "bright" (equivalent to "light rich"), "pale" ("light dull"), "deep" ("dark rich"), and "weak" ("dark dull"). These can be amplified like the other four, except that "pale" goes to "paler", "palest", and then to "palemax" or (its equivalent) "palemost", where only the word length is checked. The case of adjectives doesn't matter here; they can be all-caps, all lower-case, or mixed-case without issues. The names of colors, however, are case-sensitive, because you can combine other named color palettes with the one here, and at least in one common situation (merging libGDX Colors with the palette here), the other palette uses all-caps names only.
      If part of a color name or adjective is invalid, it is not considered; if the description is empty or fully invalid, this returns the invalid "color" PLACEHOLDER (also used by TextraTypist, and suggested as a placeholder for other code).
      Examples of valid descriptions include "blue", "dark green", "duller red", "peach pink", "indigo purple mauve", "lightest richer apricot-olive", "bright magenta", "palest cyan blue", "deep fern black", "weakmost celery", "red:3 orange", and "dark deep (blue 7) (cyan 3)".
      This overload always considers its input a color description, and won't parse hex colors. It only handles the simplest case, where the full provided description is only a color description.
      Parameters:
      description - a color description, as a String matching the above format
      Returns:
      a packed RGBA8888 int color as described

    • describeRgb

      public static int describeRgb(String description, int start, int length)
      Parses a color description and returns the approximate color it describes, as an RGBA8888 int color. Color descriptions consist of one or more alphabetical words, separated by non-alphanumeric characters (typically spaces and/or hyphens, though the underscore is treated as a letter). Any word that is the name of a color in DescriptiveColorRgb will be looked up in DescriptiveColor.NAMED and tracked; if there is more than one of these color names, the colors will be mixed using unevenMix(int[], int, int), or if there is just one color name, then the corresponding color will be used. A number can be present after a color name (separated by any non-alphanumeric character(s) other than the underscore); if so, it acts as a positive weight for that color when mixed with other named colors. The recommended separator between a color name and its weight is the space ' ', but other punctuation like ':', or whitespace, is usually valid. Note that in some contexts, color descriptions shouldn't contain square brackets, curly braces, or the chars @%?^=. , because they can have unintended effects on the behavior of markup. You can also repeat a color name to increase its weight, as in "red red blue".
      The special adjectives "light" and "dark" change the lightness of the described color; likewise, "rich" and "dull" change the saturation (how different the color is from grayscale). All of these adjectives can have "-er" or "-est" appended to make their effect twice or three times as strong. Technically, the chars appended to an adjective don't matter, only their count, so "lightaa" is the same as "lighter" and "richcat" is the same as "richest". There's an unofficial fourth level as well, used when any 4 characters are appended to an adjective (as in "darkmost"); it has four times the effect of the original adjective. There are also the adjectives "bright" (equivalent to "light rich"), "pale" ("light dull"), "deep" ("dark rich"), and "weak" ("dark dull"). These can be amplified like the other four, except that "pale" goes to "paler", "palest", and then to "palemax" or (its equivalent) "palemost", where only the word length is checked.
      Note that while adjectives are case-insensitive, color names are not. Because the colors defined in libGDX 'Colors' use ALL_CAPS, and the colors additionally defined by DescriptiveColorRgb use lower case and are always one word, there are a few places where two different colors are defined by names that only differ in case. Examples include orange vs. ORANGE, and salmon vs. SALMON.
      If part of a color name or adjective is invalid, it is not considered; if the description is empty or fully invalid, this returns the RGBA8888 int value 256 (PLACEHOLDER).
      Examples of valid descriptions include "blue", "dark green", "duller red", "peach pink", "indigo purple mauve", "lightest richer apricot-olive", "bright magenta", "palest cyan blue", "deep fern black", "weakmost celery", "red:3 orange", and "dark deep (blue 7) (cyan 3)".
      Parameters:
      description - a color description, as a String matching the above format
      start - the first character index of the description to read from
      length - how much of description to attempt to parse; if negative, this parses until the end
      Returns:
      an RGBA8888 int color as described

    • differentiateLightness

      public static int differentiateLightness(int mainColor, int contrastingColor)
      Given an RGBA8888 int color mainColor and another RGBA8888 int color that it should be made to contrast with, gets an RGBA8888 int color with lightness that should be quite different from contrastingColor's, but similar hue/chroma and opacity. This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of contrastingColor, or vice versa.
      Parameters:
      mainColor - an RGBA8888 int color; this is the color that will be adjusted
      contrastingColor - an RGBA8888 int color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the lightness of this
      Returns:
      a different RGBA8888 int color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness

    • differentiateLightness

      public static int differentiateLightness(int mainColor, float contrastingLightness)
      Given an RGBA8888 int color mainColor and a lightness value that it should be made to contrast with, gets an RGBA8888 int color with lightness that should be quite different from contrastingLightness, but similar hue/chroma and opacity. This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background with contrastingLightness for its lightness, or vice versa. The contrasting lightness is often obtained from another color, such as with lightness(int), and can be adjusted as long as it stays in the 0 to 1 range (inclusive).
      Parameters:
      mainColor - an RGBA8888 int color; this is the color that will be adjusted
      contrastingLightness - a float in the 0 to 1 range (inclusive) that the result should contrast with
      Returns:
      a different RGBA8888 int color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness

    • offsetLightness

      public static int offsetLightness(int rgba)
      Adds 0.5 to the given color's lightness(int) and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that with the original lightness. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all results in the middle-range of possible lightness. This is not at all as simple internally as the method that does the same thing on Oklab colors, and this might be best not to call on many things every frame. It might not be a bottleneck for any given application, though.
      Parameters:
      rgba - an RGBA8888 int color
      Returns:
      a different RGBA8888 int color, with its lightness changed

    • editHsl

      public static int editHsl(int rgba, float addH, float addS, float addL)
      Given an RGBA8888 int color, this converts it to HSL(A) color space and adds the remaining 3 parameters to hue, saturation, and lightness, respectively, before converting back to RGBA8888 and returning that. This can be useful for things like fading a color to grayscale (if addS is -1 or less, the result will be grayscale), hue rotations (by repeatedly adding to hue over time using addH), or combinations of similar effects with lightness changes.
      Parameters:
      rgba - an RGBA8888 int color
      addH - will be added to hue, wrapping around if hue exceeds 1.0 or goes below 0.0
      addS - will be added to saturation; can't produce saturation below 0.0
      addL - will be added to lightness; can't produce lightness below 0.0
      Returns:
      a different RGBA8888 int color, potentially with various qualities changed

    • evaluateHsl

      @Beta public static int evaluateHsl(int rgba, @Nullable com.github.tommyettinger.function.FloatToFloatFunction hueTransform, @Nullable com.github.tommyettinger.function.FloatToFloatFunction saturationTransform, @Nullable com.github.tommyettinger.function.FloatToFloatFunction lightnessTransform)
      Converts rgba to the HSL (hue, saturation, lightness) color space temporarily, runs zero to three functions on any or all of its hue, saturation, and lightness, then converts back to an RGBA8888 int color and returns that. The functions should expect a float argument in the [0, 1] range, and generally should return a float in the same range representing the same channel (hue, saturation, or lightness). Some validation is performed; all channels have a minimum of 0, and hue will wrap to be in the [0, 1[ range for any finite input.
      Parameters:
      rgba - an RGBA8888 int color
      hueTransform - a function that, if non-null, will be used to change the hue of the modified color
      saturationTransform - a function that, if non-null, will be used to change the saturation of the modified color
      lightnessTransform - a function that, if non-null, will be used to change the lightness of the modified color
      Returns:
      a potentially-modified version of rgba, still as an RGBA8888 int

    • evaluateHcl

      @Beta public static int evaluateHcl(int rgba, @Nullable com.github.tommyettinger.function.FloatToFloatFunction hueTransform, @Nullable com.github.tommyettinger.function.FloatToFloatFunction chromaTransform, @Nullable com.github.tommyettinger.function.FloatToFloatFunction lightnessTransform)
      Converts rgba to the HCL (hue, chroma, lightness) color space temporarily, runs zero to three functions on any or all of its hue, chroma, and lightness, then converts back to an RGBA8888 int color and returns that. The functions should expect a float argument in the [0, 1] range, and generally should return a float in the same range representing the same channel (hue, chroma, or lightness). Some validation is performed; all channels have a minimum of 0, and hue will wrap to be in the [0, 1[ range for any finite input.
      Parameters:
      rgba - an RGBA8888 int color
      hueTransform - a function that, if non-null, will be used to change the hue of the modified color
      chromaTransform - a function that, if non-null, will be used to change the chroma of the modified color
      lightnessTransform - a function that, if non-null, will be used to change the lightness of the modified color
      Returns:
      a potentially-modified version of rgba, still as an RGBA8888 int

    • evaluateHsb

      @Beta public static int evaluateHsb(int rgba, @Nullable com.github.tommyettinger.function.FloatToFloatFunction hueTransform, @Nullable com.github.tommyettinger.function.FloatToFloatFunction saturationTransform, @Nullable com.github.tommyettinger.function.FloatToFloatFunction brightnessTransform)
      Converts rgba to the HSB (hue, saturation, brightness) color space temporarily, runs zero to three functions on any or all of its hue, saturation, and brightness, then converts back to an RGBA8888 int color and returns that. The functions should expect a float argument in the [0, 1] range, and generally should return a float in the same range representing the same channel (hue, saturation, or brightness). Some validation is performed; all channels have a minimum of 0, and hue will wrap to be in the [0, 1[ range for any finite input.
      Parameters:
      rgba - an RGBA8888 int color
      hueTransform - a function that, if non-null, will be used to change the hue of the modified color
      saturationTransform - a function that, if non-null, will be used to change the saturation of the modified color
      brightnessTransform - a function that, if non-null, will be used to change the brightness of the modified color
      Returns:
      a potentially-modified version of rgba, still as an RGBA8888 int

    • distanceSquared

      public static float distanceSquared(int rgba0, int rgba1)
      Gets the squared Euclidean distance between two colors as RGBA8888 ints. This is a very approximate measure of how different two colors are from each other, and is typically less correlated to perceptual difference than distanceSquaredOklab(int, int) the distance in Oklab color space}. The result should typically be rather small; each RGB channel can only be 1 unit of distance apart at most, so the maximum squared distance is 3. Note that this is squared, so it isn't an admissible metric for some usage, like summing up distances.
      Parameters:
      rgba0 - an RGBA8888 int color
      rgba1 - an RGBA8888 int color
      Returns:
      the squared Euclidean distance between rgba0 and rgba1 in RGB space; never greater than 3.0f

    • distance

      public static float distance(int rgba0, int rgba1)
      Gets the actual Euclidean distance between two colors as RGBA8888 ints. This is an approximate measure of how different two colors are from each other, and is typically less correlated to perceptual difference than distanceOklab(int, int) the distance in Oklab color space}. The result should typically be rather small; each RGB channel can only be 1 unit of distance apart at most, so the maximum distance is Math.sqrt(3), or 1.7320508f. Note that this is not squared, so unlike distanceSquared(int, int), it is an admissible metric for things like summing up distances.
      Parameters:
      rgba0 - an RGBA8888 int color
      rgba1 - an RGBA8888 int color
      Returns:
      the Euclidean distance between rgba0 and rgba1 in RGB space; never greater than 1.7320508f

    • distanceSquaredOklab

      public static float distanceSquaredOklab(int rgba0, int rgba1)
      Gets the squared difference between two colors, each RGBA8888 ints, calculating the difference by the squared Euclidean distance in the Oklab color space. This is a very approximate measure of how different two colors are from each other, but in Oklab this measurement is relatively more accurate than if you used plain RGB as the color space. The result should typically be rather small; lightness can only be 1 unit of distance apart at most (from black to white), and the A and B channels are usually just a tiny bit away from the vertical lightness axis. A result of 1 may be the largest this can produce, but it is very possible that somewhat larger results can happen. Note that this is squared, so it isn't an admissible metric for some usage, like summing up distances. You can use distanceOklab(int, int) as a metric, though.
      Parameters:
      rgba0 - an RGBA8888 int color
      rgba1 - an RGBA8888 int color
      Returns:
      the squared Euclidean distance between rgba0 and rgba1 in Oklab space; usually less than 1.0f

    • distanceOklab

      public static float distanceOklab(int rgba0, int rgba1)
      Gets the difference between two colors, each RGBA8888 ints, calculating the difference by the Euclidean distance in the Oklab color space. This is an approximate measure of how different two colors are from each other, but in Oklab this measurement is relatively more accurate than if you used plain RGB as the color space. The result should typically be rather small; lightness can only be 1 unit of distance apart at most (from black to white), and the A and B channels are usually just a tiny bit away from the vertical lightness axis. A result of 1 may be the largest this can produce, but it is very possible that somewhat larger results can happen. Note that this is not squared, so unlike distanceSquaredOklab(int, int), it is an admissible metric for things like summing up distances.
      Parameters:
      rgba0 - an RGBA8888 int color
      rgba1 - an RGBA8888 int color
      Returns:
      the Euclidean distance between rgba0 and rgba1 in Oklab space; usually less than 1.0f
